results.title: Akira [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Akira Committee, Ryohei Suzuki, Shunzo Kato and Katsuhiro Otomo
results.brief_description: Akira is set in Neo-Tokyo, 2019. The city is rebuilding after World War III. Kaneda and Tetsuo, two high-school dropouts, are members of a joy-riding motorcycle gang. They stumble upon a secret government project to develop telekinetic humans, apparently for use as weapons. The most powerful of these subjects is Akira, a being shrouded in mystery. The film is based on the popular graphic novel of the same name, which has achieved cult status in Japan. Animation and visual effects are outstanding in this spectacular and often disturbing vision of urban apocalypse. NB: THIS IS NOT A CHILDRENS’ FEATURE AND IS RECOMMENDED FOR MATURE AUDIENCES.

results.title: Akiko: the life of a Japanese girl
results.brief_description: Shows a Japanese girl engaged in the study of the traditional japanese arts of drawing, painting, and using vegetable dyes. Shows how western lifestyle and culture is blending with the traditional Japanese way of life

results.title: Aki no ichinichi = A Day in autumn
results.brief_description: Educational film in Japanese language studying Japanese culture. A family outing on an autumn day in a rural area meeting with local farmers and having a picnic.

results.title: Akermania: shorter works by Chantal Akerman [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Chantal Akerman, one of contemporary cinema’s singular filmmakers, is the director of these three engaging short films about women finding their way in the world. “I’m hungry, I’m cold”: Two young Belgian girls run away from home in Brussels. They spend a day and an evening looking for food and love, with comic and poignant results. Stars Maria de Medeiros. “Blow up my town”: A young woman (Akerman) comes home to her apartment in Brussels where she cooks pasta and seals herself in with duct tape. An amusing and wonderfully observational piece, evocative of early Buster Keaton work with its virtually dialogue-less track, Akerman’s first film was made at the age of 18. “Hotel Monterey”: A stark and silent look at a New York pension hotel, Akerman roams the corridors, stairwells, lifts and crammed apartments of the dwelling, looking for signs of life, human interaction and connections between the inhabitants. This experimental piece, reminiscent of the 1970s work of Andy Warhol, is considered in many ways a non-narrative study for “Jeanne Dielman” Akerman’s iconic 1975 feminist, experimental feature.

results.title: Akahige = Red beard (Cinemascope Print)
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Kurosawa Productions, Tomoyuki Tanaka, Ryuzo Kikushima and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
Under the guidance of an aging, autocratic doctor, an arrogant, socially ambitious new intern learns the rewards of treating the poor in a public health clinic in this social drama that followed ‘Sanjuro’, the final film in Kurosawa’s samurai trilogy. While vaguely cyclical the complex narrative lacks a clear over-riding structure. Rather, it is purposely amorphous, full of incident and detail, sentiment and poetic fantasy. The film took over two years to shoot with Kurosawa going to painstaking lengths to achieve a realistic reconstruction of 19th-century feudal Japan. Also available on 16mm.

Credits: Producers, Tomoyuki Tanaka, Ryuzo Kikushima ; director, Akira Kurosawa ; writers, Akira Kurosawa, Ryuzo Kikushima, Hideo Iguni, Masato Ide ; photography, Asaichi Nakai, Takao Saito ; music, Masaru Sato.
Cast: Toshiro Mifune, Yuzo Kayama, Tsutomu Yamazaki, Kyoko Kagawa, Terumi Niki, Kamatari Fujiwara.

results.title: Ak: Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
Chris Marker follows the arduous location shooting of ‘Ran’, profiling Kurosawa and his collaborators, examining the director’s techniques, and placing the film in context with his previous work.

Credits: Producer, Serge Silberman ; director, Chris Marker ; photography, Franz-Yves Marescot ; music, Toru Takemitsu.

results.title: Airway
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Life Support”.
Explains the anatomy of the upper and lower airway and, how simply it can become partially or totally blocked; the signs and symptoms of a partially blocked and totally blocked airway and the emergency treatment required under both conditions.

results.title: Airport in the jet age
results.brief_description: A boy has an adventure through the reading of a book, one that takes him in a helicopter to the airport. There he checks in, boards his jet airliner, and takes off. No trouble at all, it seems. But then the film takes us back to watch the scores of people who work together to make this take-off possible.

results.title: Airplanes: how they fly
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Hal Kopel
results.brief_description: Two children learn from a model airplane enthusiast how an airplane’s wings keep it in the air and how the propeller makes it move forward. The children go for an airplane ride and the pilot demonstrates the controls and explains how they work.
